facts.text: Appellant Raghubansh Lal was Patwari of village Arazi Mafi Pandai and a public servant.
Two brothers, Mahadeo and Sahdeo, members of joint Hindu family, owned certain plots of land including Nos. 170 and 74/1.
Mahadeo died leaving widow Basera Kunwar, son Damodar Pande and daughter Mahura Kuer.
Sahdeo died leaving widow Sundra Kuer.
On death of Damodar Pande, Ram Sewak Pande brought suit against Basera Kunwar and Sundra Kuer for possession of zamindari property including sir and sayar left by Damodar, which was dismissed.
On death of Basera Kunwar, Adit Pande (son of Ram Sewak) and Ganga Pande got names mutated in regard to this property.
Smt. Mahura Kuar brought suit for possession of estate left by Basera Kunwar against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande, decreed on August 1, 1941.
On May 31, 1943, Smt. Mahura Kuar obtained possession through Court of this estate including plots Nos. 170 and 74/1.
On February 25, 1950, Mahura Kuer applied to Sub-Divisional Magistrate for proceedings under s.145 CrPC against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande.
Magistrate ordered attachment of land including plots 170 and 74/1 on March 15, 1950; possession given to Shubh Karan as sapurdar.
Property under attachment from March 15, 1950 to December 18, 1950, comprising part of 1357 F and part of 1358 F.
On December 18, 1950, s.145 proceedings ended in favour of Mahura Kuar; possession established; Adit and Ganga restrained; attachment ended; possession to be handed to Mahura Kuar.
Revision by opposite party to District Magistrate dismissed on March 28, 1951; actual possession delivered in April 1951.
Delivery of possession stayed from December 1950 to April 1951 under District Magistrate's order.

On July 31, 1951, Smt. Mahura Kuar filed complaint under s.218 IPC against appellant in Judicial Magistrate Court at Ghazipur, alleging wrong entries in khasra for plots 170 and 74/1, remarks column showing Adit Pande in possession.
Case committed to Court of Session; prosecution witnesses: Mahura Kuer (PW1), Gouri Shankar (PW2), Naresh (PW3).
Defence witnesses: Adit Pande (DW1), Ram Swarup (DW2).
Accused's plea: Knew from Shubh Karan that Mahura won s.145 case, but spot possession with Adit Pande; did not act per Magistrate order as no order received; Mahura not in actual possession.
Trial court convicted accused under s.218 IPC, sentenced to 1 year RI and fine Rs.200 or 4 months RI in default.
Allahabad High Court confirmed trial court's decision, relying on statements of Mahura, Gauri Shankar, Naresh; held entries incorrect with intent to injure Mahura.
Khasra entries for 1358 F in remarks column: 'qabiz badastur' (possession as before), naming Adit Pande.
Shubh Karan (sapurdar) not examined as witness.
Actual physical possession to Mahura in April 1951; not before that during attachment.
Entries made somewhere in March (presumably 1951).

legal_issues.text: Whether the accused knowingly framed the khasra record in an incorrect manner with intent to cause or knowing it likely to cause loss or injury to Smt. Mahura Kuar under s.218 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Came to know from Shubh Karan that Mahura won s.145 case, but spot possession was of Adit Pande; did not receive Magistrate's order; did not find Mahura in actual possession.
Sapurdar Shubhkaran never got possession from Adit Pande; absence of Shubhkaran's testimony creates doubt.
No criminal intention proved; direct evidence lacking, circumstantial evidence meagre.

respondent_arguments.text: Accused deliberately made wrong entries in khasra for plots 170 and 74/1, entering Adit Pande's name in possession in remarks column.
Delivery of possession to Mahura proved by her statement and PW2, PW3; Shubh Karan sowed crops; physical possession in April 1951.
Accused knew of litigation; entries incorrect with view to injure Mahura.
Entry could help Adit under s.16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition Act (though court notes it's 1358F not 1356F).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951

court_reasoning.text: Courts below considered s.145 proceedings, but land attached and given to Shubhkaran; actual possession to Mahura only April 1951.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mahura not in physical possession during attachment period.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution must prove: (1) knowingly framed incorrect record; (2) with intent/knowledge to cause loss/injury to public or Mahura.
Accused knew of litigation but entry for 1358F made in March after s.145 decision in Dec 1950; could not affect s.145 or help under s.16 Zamindari Act (which requires 1356F).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No loss could result from entry.

court_reasoning.text: Direct evidence of intention lacking; circumstantial evidence too meagre.
Rule 60 U.P. Land Records Manual requires entries per actual facts by inquiry and inspection by April 30.

holdings.text: Prosecution failed to prove necessary criminal intention under s.218 IPC; no offence committed.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Framing incorrect record as public servant with intent to cause loss/injury.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings establishing possession of Mahura Kuar.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Land Records Manual
statutes_cited.relevance: Preparation of khasras based on actual facts by Patwari.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems recorded occupant in 1356 F as hereditary tenant; entry not for that year.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of conviction by trial court and High Court set aside; appellant acquitted of offence under s.218 IPC.

key_quotes.text: in order to sustain the conviction it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect, it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core legal test for s.218 IPC.

key_quotes.text: Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is difficult to see how any wrong entry in regard to the year 1358 F could cause any loss to the complainant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
